title: Like those diamond earrings? Rent them
text:
Lauren Sams Luxury Editor Oct 30, 2019 — 10.52am Share

Call it the Airbnb – or Uber, or Netflix – effect: renting is the new owning. And while the booming market in rentals is nothing new – these days, you can hire anything from a wedding dress to a pasta maker and a desk in a co-working space – the concept is fast expanding into the luxury sphere. Not only can you rent that handbag or evening gown; you can now rent the jewels to go with it.

Piggybacking on the success of the pioneering fashion rental company Rent the Runway, companies including the US-based Flont, Haute Vault and Switch now offer one-off and subscription-based jewellery hire services. And it’s not just costume jewellery up for grabs – semi-precious and fine jewellery from the likes of Cartier, Tiffany and Van Cleef & Arpels is available to rent. For $US188 (about $275), for instance, Flont will let you borrow a pair of Chopard Happy Diamond earrings, worth $US4600 retail.

A set of three First Blush bracelets by Roxanne Assoulin: rent them from Switch.

Switch, one of a number of American jewel rental start-ups, offers subscription plans starting from $US29 a month. Members can choose a number of pieces and keep them for “as long as they like” before returning them for more. Members also earn credit that can be put towards purchasing pieces. Known for its selection of vintage jewellery, Switch offers items from Chanel, Hermès, Yves Saint Laurent and Dior.

In June, The New York Times declared that “owning nothing is now a luxury” – renting is not merely about convenience and cost, it's about status.

A gold-toned Coco Chanel vintage necklace, available from Switch.

In The State of Fashion 2019 report, written jointly by Business of Fashion and Mckinsey, the growth of rental is attributed to “growing consumer desire for variety, sustainability and affordability”. And, of course, consumers are not exclusively renting – more and more, renting is a prelude to purchasing, particularly when it comes to watch hire.

You'll look the part in this Audemars Piguet Royal Oak Offshore Safari chronograph. Find it at Acquired Time.

Acquired Time, a Singapore-based watch rental start-up, offers subscription services starting at $S175 ($188) a month for a minimum of six months (at which price point IWC Pilot’s Chronographs and Omega Speedmasters are available). For the top tier of $S575 you can upgrade to a Rolex GMT Master II, worth about $28,000.

The service, says co-founder Roy Tong, is seen as a way to build on existing watch collections and effectively try before you buy.
description: As rental services become more popular and mainstream, it seems you can hire just about anything – including fine jewellery.
